tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This psalm is a prayer for help.
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"
This may refer to a style of music. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:045:001|45:1]].
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

tn.ref: for the waters have put my life in danger
tn.text: The writer describes the troubles in his life as if he were drowning in a flood of water. AT: "for it feels like I am drowning in the waters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The writer describes the troubles in his life as if he were sinking in deep mud. AT: "For it feels like I am sinking in deep mud and will die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
thick mud

tn.ref: there is no place to stand
tn.text: The writer uses a negative statement to stress how unstable and uncertain his condition is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: I have come into deep waters, where the floods flow over me
tn.text: The writer describes his problems as if he was drowning in a deep, raging river. AT: "t feels like I am in deep waters, and the floodwaters flow over me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
very tired
This idiom means the writer has cried so much that his eyes do not see well any longer. AT: "my eyes are swollen from tears" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: more than the hairs on my head
tn.text: This is an exaggeration to express how many enemies the writer has. AT: "more than I can count, like the hairs on my head" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This idiom means "kill me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The abstract noun "foolishness" can be stated as an action. AT: "the foolish things that I have done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: my sins are not hidden from you
tn.text: This can be expressed as a positive statement. AT: "you know all my sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: those who wait for you be put to shame ... those who seek you be brought to dishonor
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize the writer's desire to have God protect his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Let not those who wait for you be put to shame because of me
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Please do not put to shame because of me those who wait for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Do not let those"

tn.ref: let not those who seek you be brought to dishonor because of me
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Please do not bring dishonor because of me on those who seek you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Seeking God represents either 1) asking God for help or 2) thinking about God and obeying him. AT: 1) "those who ask you for help" or 2) "those who worship and obey you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"On your behalf" or "For you"
The rebukes of the writer's enemies are spoken of as if they are a heavy load that he has had to carry. AT: "I have endured the insults of my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The writer speaks of the shame that he feels as if it is a foul thing on his face that everyone can clearly see. AT: "I am thoroughly humiliated" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I have become a stranger to my brothers
tn.text: The writer speaks of himself as if he were not part of his own family. AT: "My brothers no longer know or accept me at all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: a stranger to my brothers ... an alien to my mother's children
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing. They are repeated to stress his separation from his own family. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: an alien to my mother's children
tn.text: It is implied that "I have become" should be understood here. The writer speaks of himself as if he were not part of his own family. AT: "my brothers no longer know or trust me at all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the zeal of your house has eaten me up
tn.text: The writer speaks of his zeal for God's temple as if it was a wild animal that devours the writer. AT: "the zeal I have for your house consumes me"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This idiom means that the writer's zeal for the temple takes over all of his thoughts and actions. AT: "completely controls all that I think and do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: the rebukes ... have fallen on me
tn.text: The writer speaks of the rebukes of Gods' enemies as if they were rocks that were thrown at the writer. AT: "those who rebuke you have also thrown their rebukes at me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I wept and did not eat food
tn.text: The fact that the writer was fasting indicates that he was sad about the way people treated God's temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"my enemies rebuked me because of it"
Wearing rough, cheap clothing was a symbol of mourning over sin. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: I became the object of a proverb
tn.text: The writer speak of himself as if he was the sad or foolish person in a proverb. AT: "I became the example of a sad person spoken of in their proverbs" or "they laugh at me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Those who sit in the city gate
tn.text: Here "city gate" is associated with leadership of a town. AT: "The important people of the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I am a song of drunkards
tn.text: The writer speaks of himself as if he was the person about whom the drunkards sing mocking songs. AT: "the drunkards of the city sing disgusting songs about me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: at a time that you will accept
tn.text: "in your accepted time" or "when you are willing"

tn.ref: answer me in the trustworthiness of your salvation
tn.text: The abstract nouns "trustworthiness" and "salvation" can be stated as actions. AT: "rescue me because you faithfully love me, as you have promised to do" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: Pull me out ... do not let me sink
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Pull me out of the mire, and do not let me sink
tn.text: The writer speaks of his danger from his enemies as if he was sinking into a pit of mud. "Do not allow me to sink anymore in the mud" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "take away" refers to being removed from danger. This can be stated in active form. AT: "take me away" or "rescue me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

It is understood that "let me be" is implied here. It can be stated in active form. AT: "please rescue me out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the deep water ... the floods of water ... the deep
tn.text: These phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: rescued out of the deep waters
tn.text: The writer speaks about his danger from his enemies as if he was drowning in deep water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the floods of water overwhelm me
tn.text: The writer speaks about his danger from his enemies as if flood waters were covering him completely. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The writer speaks of the deep as if it was a deadly animal that was about to eat him. AT: "the deep waters swallow me up like a dangerous animal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Do not let the pit shut its mouth on me
tn.text: Here the "pit" is spoken of as if it has a mouth like a person and could eat the writer. AT: "Do not let the pit consume me" or "Do not let the pit of death close over me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The abstract term "covenant faithfulness" can be stated as an action. AT: "you are good and love me faithfully" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: your mercies for me are many
tn.text: "you are very merciful to me"
The idea of turning towards someone means to pay attention to them or help them. AT: "help me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Do not hide your face from your servant
tn.text: To hide one's face means to refuse to hear or help someone. AT: "Please help your servant" or "Please help me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"in great trouble" (UDB)
The writer asks God to redeem him as if the writer were a slave whose freedom God could purchase. AT: "free me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The writer asks God to ransom him as if the writer were a captive whose release could be paid for with money. AT: "rescue me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: my rebuke, my shame, and my dishonor
tn.text: These abstract nouns can be stated as actions. AT: "how people have rebuked me, shamed me, and dishonored me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: my adversaries are all before you
tn.text: Here "before you" means that God sees and knows all about them. AT: "you know who all my enemies are" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means a person is extremely sad. AT: "offended me deeply" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The writer's great sadness is spoken of as if he was full of a heavy weight. AT: "I am heavy with sorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
to feel sorrow or sadness

tn.ref: They gave me poison for my food
tn.text: This is probably figurative. The   food that people gave to the writer was so bad that it tasted like poison. AT: "They gave me food that tasted like poison" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Let their table before them become a snare ... let it become a trap
tn.text: The writer would like for his enemies' food to completely ruin them as if they were small animals caught in a snare or a trap. AT: "May their food ruin them like a snare ... may it destroy them like a trap" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to food that was served on the tables, possibly at a feast. AT: "their own food" (UDB) or "sacrificial feasts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The writer speaks of eyes that cannot see well as if they were darkened. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Please make them unable to see anything" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Weak backs are spoken of as if they are shaking in weakness. AT: "cause their backs to be too weak for them to do anything" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"their sides" or "their backs"

tn.ref: Pour out your indignation on them
tn.text: God's demonstration of his anger is described as if he poured it out on his enemies like water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"rage" or "anger"
"your burning anger" or "your strong anger"
God's judgment on his enemies is described as if he ran after them and caught them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This abstract noun can be stated as an action. AT: "become abandoned" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"they persecuted the man"
Here to be "struck down" refers to punishment. AT: "you punished" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here to be "wounded" refers to causing them to suffer. AT: "those you have caused to suffer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Accuse them of having committed iniquity after iniquity
tn.text: "Keep making a record of all their sins" (UDB)
"very many sins"

tn.ref: do not let them come into your righteous victory
tn.text: To come into God's victory is an idiom that means to receive a reward from him. AT: "do not let them receive your righteous reward" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Let them be blotted out of
tn.text: Here "them" refers to the names of the enemies. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Wipe out their names in" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

It is inferred that "let them" is understood. This can be stated in active form.  AT: "do not write down their names" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: let your salvation, God, set me up on high
tn.text: The abstract noun "salvation" can be stated with the verb "save." Here "on high" refers to a place of safety." AT: "God, save me and put me in a safe place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "name" refers to God himself. AT: "God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This abstract noun can be stated with the verb "thank." AT: "by thanking him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: better than an ox or a bull
tn.text: It is understood that the ox and the bull are to be offered to God as sacrifices. AT: "better than sacrificing an ox or sacrificing a bull" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: a bull that has horns and hooves
tn.text: This phrase distinguishes the full grown bulls from other younger cows. AT: "a bull that is full grown with horns and hooves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_distinguish]])
This refers to meek people in general. AT: "Meek people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

Seeking God represents either 1) asking God for help or 2) thinking about God and obeying him. AT: "you who ask God for help" or "you who think about God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "hearts" refer to the people. Here "live" is an idiom that means to be encouraged. AT: "may you be encouraged" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
Here "hears" means to respond. AT: "Yahweh answers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to needy people in general. AT: "needy people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"those who have suffered for him" (UDB)

tn.ref: Let heaven and earth praise him ... the seas
tn.text: Here heaven and earth and the seas are spoken of as if they are people who are able to praise God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: the seas and everything that moves in them
tn.text: It is implied that "Let ... praise him" should be understood here. AT: "let he seas and everything that moves in them praise him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Here "Zion" refers to the people in Zion. AT: "God will save the people of Zion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "it" refers to the land of Judah.
Here "name" refers to God himself. AT: "who love God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
